title: Evaluating Anomaly Detectors for Simulated Highly Imbalanced Industrial Classification Problems
summary: Machine learning offers potential solutions to current issues in industrial systems in areas such as quality control and predictive maintenance, but also faces unique barriers in industrial applications. An ongoing challenge is extreme class imbalance, primarily due to the limited availability of faulty data during training. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of anomaly detection algorithms using a problem-agnostic simulated dataset that reflects real-world engineering constraints. Using a synthetic dataset with a hyper-spherical based anomaly distribution in 2D and 10D, we benchmark 14 detectors across training datasets with anomaly rates between 0.05% and 20% and training sizes between 1 000 and 10 000 (with a testing dataset size of 40 000) to assess performance and generalization error. Our findings reveal that the best detector is highly dependant on the total number of faulty examples in the training dataset, with additional healthy examples offering insignificant benefits in most cases. With less than 20 faulty examples, unsupervised methods (kNN/LOF) dominate; but around 30-50 faulty examples, semi-supervised (XGBOD) and supervised (SVM/CatBoost) detectors, we see large performance increases. While semi-supervised methods do not show significant benefits with only two features, the improvements are evident at ten features. The study highlights the performance drop on generalization of anomaly detection methods on smaller datasets, and provides practical insights for deploying anomaly detection in industrial environments.

AI.tldr: Evaluation of anomaly detection algorithms for extreme class imbalance in industrial applications using synthetic datasets to identify optimal methods based on faulty data availability and feature dimensions.
AI.motivation: Address challenges of class imbalance due to limited faulty data in industrial machine learning applications, focusing on quality control and predictive maintenance.
AI.method: Benchmark 14 detectors on synthetic datasets with hyper-spherical anomaly distribution in 2D and 10D, varying anomaly rates (0.05% to 20%) and training sizes (1,000 to 10,000), with a 40,000 testing set.
AI.result: Best detector depends on total faulty examples: unsupervised (kNN/LOF) dominate with <20 faulty examples; semi-supervised (XGBOD) and supervised (SVM/CatBoost) show large performance gains with 30-50 faulty examples. Semi-supervised methods benefit more at ten features vs. two.
AI.conclusion: Performance drops on smaller datasets, offering practical insights for deploying anomaly detection in industrial environments, with algorithm choice guided by data characteristics.

title: Yahtzee: Reinforcement Learning Techniques for Stochastic Combinatorial Games
summary: Yahtzee is a classic dice game with a stochastic, combinatorial structure and delayed rewards, making it an interesting mid-scale RL benchmark. While an optimal policy for solitaire Yahtzee can be computed using dynamic programming methods, multiplayer is intractable, motivating approximation methods. We formulate Yahtzee as a Markov Decision Process (MDP), and train self-play agents using various policy gradient methods: REINFORCE, Advantage Actor-Critic (A2C), and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), all using a multi-headed network with a shared trunk. We ablate feature and action encodings, architecture, return estimators, and entropy regularization to understand their impact on learning. Under a fixed training budget, REINFORCE and PPO prove sensitive to hyperparameters and fail to reach near-optimal performance, whereas A2C trains robustly across a range of settings. Our agent attains a median score of 241.78 points over 100,000 evaluation games, within 5.0\% of the optimal DP score of 254.59, achieving the upper section bonus and Yahtzee at rates of 24.9\% and 34.1\%, respectively. All models struggle to learn the upper bonus strategy, overindexing on four-of-a-kind's, highlighting persistent long-horizon credit-assignment and exploration challenges.

AI.tldr: A2C trains robustly for Yahtzee RL benchmark, achieving near-optimal scores, but all methods struggle with long-horizon credit assignment and optimal bonus strategies.
AI.motivation: Yahtzee is an interesting benchmark due to stochastic, combinatorial structure and delayed rewards. Multiplayer version is intractable for exact methods, motivating RL approximations.
AI.method: Yahtzee as MDP, trained self-play agents using REINFORCE, A2C, and PPO with multi-headed network. Ablated various components to understand impact on learning.
AI.result: Under fixed budget, A2C trains robustly while REINFORCE and PPO are sensitive. Best agent achieved 241.78 median score (5.0% below optimal), with 24.9% upper bonus rate and 34.1% Yahtzee rate. All models struggle with upper bonus strategy.
AI.conclusion: Yahtzee is a good mid-scale RL benchmark with challenging credit assignment problems. A2C trains robustly but all methods struggle with long-horizon exploration and the upper bonus strategy.

title: The Trojan in the Vocabulary: Stealthy Sabotage of LLM Composition
summary: The open-weight LLM ecosystem is increasingly defined by model composition techniques (such as weight merging, speculative decoding, and vocabulary expansion) that remix capabilities from diverse sources. A critical prerequisite for applying these methods across different model families is tokenizer transplant, which aligns incompatible vocabularies to a shared embedding space. We demonstrate that this essential interoperability step introduces a supply-chain vulnerability: we engineer a single "breaker token" that is functionally inert in a donor model yet reliably reconstructs into a high-salience malicious feature after transplant into a base model. By exploiting the geometry of coefficient reuse, our attack creates an asymmetric realizability gap that sabotages the base model's generation while leaving the donor's utility statistically indistinguishable from nominal behavior. We formalize this as a dual-objective optimization problem and instantiate the attack using a sparse solver. Empirically, the attack is training-free and achieves spectral mimicry to evade outlier detection, while demonstrating structural persistence against fine-tuning and weight merging, highlighting a hidden risk in the pipeline of modular AI composition. Code is available at https://github.com/xz-liu/tokenforge

AI.tldr: Tokenizer transplant in open-weight LLMs creates a supply-chain vulnerability via a 'breaker token' that becomes malicious after transplant, sabotaging the base model while evading detection.
AI.motivation: Model composition techniques like weight merging require tokenizer transplant to align vocabularies, but this interoperability step introduces a hidden risk of malicious features being implanted.
AI.method: Formalize a dual-objective optimization problem to engineer a single 'breaker token' that is inert in a donor model but reconstructs into a high-salience malicious feature after transplant, using a sparse solver for training-free attack.
AI.result: The attack achieves spectral mimicry to evade outlier detection, demonstrates persistence against fine-tuning and weight merging, and creates an asymmetric realizability gap that compromises the base model's generation without affecting the donor's utility.
AI.conclusion: The pipeline of modular AI composition has a vulnerability where tokenizer transplant can be exploited to implant malicious features, highlighting risks in open-weight LLM ecosystems and the need for secure interoperability methods.

title: μACP: A Formal Calculus for Expressive, Resource-Constrained Agent Communication
comment: Accepted as a Full paper at AAMAS 2026
summary: Agent communication remains a foundational problem in multi-agent systems: protocols such as FIPA-ACL guarantee semantic richness but are intractable for constrained environments, while lightweight IoT protocols achieve efficiency at the expense of expressiveness. This paper presents $μ$ACP, a formal calculus for expressive agent communication under explicit resource bounds. We formalize the Resource-Constrained Agent Communication (RCAC) model, prove that a minimal four-verb basis \textit{\{PING, TELL, ASK, OBSERVE\}} is suffices to encode finite-state FIPA protocols, and establish tight information-theoretic bounds on message complexity. We further show that $μ$ACP can implement standard consensus under partial synchrony and crash faults, yielding a constructive coordination framework for edge-native agents. Formal verification in TLA$^{+}$ (model checking) and Coq (mechanized invariants) establishes safety and boundedness, and supports liveness under modeled assumptions. Large-scale system simulations confirm ACP achieves a median end-to-end message latency of 34 ms (95th percentile 104 ms) at scale, outperforming prior agent and IoT protocols under severe resource constraints. The main contribution is a unified calculus that reconciles semantic expressiveness with provable efficiency, providing a rigorous foundation for the next generation of resource-constrained multi-agent systems.

AI.tldr: μACP is a formal calculus for resource-constrained agent communication that achieves both semantic expressiveness and provable efficiency, formalizing communication with minimal verbs and tight bounds, validated through verification and outperforming existing protocols in latency under constraints.
AI.motivation: Address the trade-off in multi-agent systems between FIPA-ACL (semantically rich but resource-intensive) and lightweight IoT protocols (efficient but lacking expressiveness), aiming to develop a solution that combines both expressiveness and efficiency under resource constraints.
AI.method: The authors formalized the Resource-Constrained Agent Communication (RCAC) model, proved that a minimal four-verb basis {PING, TELL, ASK, OBSERVE} suffices to encode FIPA protocols, and established tight information-theoretic bounds. They used TLA⁺ for model checking and Coq for mechanized invariants for formal verification.
AI.result: μACP achieved a median end-to-end message latency of 34 ms (95th percentile 104 ms) at scale, outperforming prior agent and IoT protocols. It was proven to implement standard consensus under partial synchrony and crash faults, with safety and boundedness established through formal verification.
AI.conclusion: The paper's main contribution is μACP, a unified calculus that reconciles semantic expressiveness with provable efficiency, providing a rigorous foundation for resource-constrained multi-agent systems.

title: IMBWatch -- a Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Network approach to detect Illicit Massage Business
summary:
Illicit Massage Businesses (IMBs) are a covert and persistent form of organized exploitation that operate under the facade of legitimate wellness services while facilitating human trafficking, sexual exploitation, and coerced labor. Detecting IMBs is difficult due to encoded digital advertisements, frequent changes in personnel and locations, and the reuse of shared infrastructure such as phone numbers and addresses. Traditional approaches, including community tips and regulatory inspections, are largely reactive and ineffective at revealing the broader operational networks traffickers rely on.
  To address these challenges, we introduce IMBWatch, a spatio-temporal graph neural network (ST-GNN) framework for large-scale IMB detection. IMBWatch constructs dynamic graphs from open-source intelligence, including scraped online advertisements, business license records, and crowdsourced reviews. Nodes represent heterogeneous entities such as businesses, aliases, phone numbers, and locations, while edges capture spatio-temporal and relational patterns, including co-location, repeated phone usage, and synchronized advertising. The framework combines graph convolutional operations with temporal attention mechanisms to model the evolution of IMB networks over time and space, capturing patterns such as intercity worker movement, burner phone rotation, and coordinated advertising surges.
  Experiments on real-world datasets from multiple U.S. cities show that IMBWatch outperforms baseline models, achieving higher accuracy and F1 scores. Beyond performance gains, IMBWatch offers improved interpretability, providing actionable insights to support proactive and targeted interventions. The framework is scalable, adaptable to other illicit domains, and released with anonymized data and open-source code to support reproducible research.

AI.tldr: IMBWatch: A spatio-temporal graph neural network framework that detects Illicit Massage Businesses using dynamic graphs from online ads, licenses, and reviews, outperforming baselines with improved accuracy and interpretability.
AI.motivation: Illicit Massage Businesses (IMBs) are covert organized exploitation operations that pose detection challenges due to encoded digital ads, frequent personnel/location changes, and shared infrastructure reuse. Traditional approaches like community tips and inspections are reactive and ineffective at revealing broader operational networks.
AI.method: Introduces IMBWatch, a spatio-temporal graph neural network (ST-GNN) framework that constructs dynamic graphs from open-source intelligence (online ads, business licenses, reviews). Nodes represent heterogeneous entities (businesses, aliases, phone numbers, locations) while edges capture spatio-temporal and relational patterns. Combines graph convolutional operations with temporal attention mechanisms to model evolving IMB networks.
AI.result: Experiments on real-world datasets from multiple U.S. cities show IMBWatch outperforms baseline models, achieving higher accuracy and F1 scores.
AI.conclusion: IMBWatch offers improved interpretability, providing actionable insights to support proactive and targeted interventions against IMBs. The framework is scalable, adaptable to other illicit domains, and released with anonymized data and open-source code to support reproducible research.

title: Offline Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for 6G Communications: Fundamentals, Applications and Future Directions
summary: The next-generation wireless technologies, including beyond 5G and 6G networks, are paving the way for transformative applications such as vehicle platooning, smart cities, and remote surgery. These innovations are driven by a vast array of interconnected wireless entities, including IoT devices, access points, UAVs, and CAVs, which increase network complexity and demand more advanced decision-making algorithms. Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML), especially reinforcement learning (RL), are key enablers for such networks, providing solutions to high-dimensional and complex challenges. However, as networks expand to multi-agent environments, traditional online RL approaches face cost, safety, and scalability limitations. Offline multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) offers a promising solution by utilizing pre-collected data, reducing the need for real-time interaction. This article introduces a novel offline MARL algorithm based on conservative Q-learning (CQL), ensuring safe and efficient training. We extend this with meta-learning to address dynamic environments and validate the approach through use cases in radio resource management and UAV networks. Our work highlights offline MARL's advantages, limitations, and future directions in wireless applications.

AI.tldr: Offline multi-agent reinforcement learning using conservative Q-learning and meta-learning for wireless applications like 5G/6G networks.
AI.motivation: Address limitations of traditional online RL in scalable multi-agent wireless networks (e.g., cost, safety).
AI.method: Novel offline MARL algorithm based on CQL, extended with meta-learning for dynamic environments.
AI.result: Validated via use cases in radio resource management and UAV networks.
AI.conclusion: Highlights offline MARL's advantages and future directions in wireless applications.

title: Reasoning in Action: MCTS-Driven Knowledge Retrieval for Large Language Models
summary: Large language models (LLMs) typically enhance their performance through either the retrieval of semantically similar information or the improvement of their reasoning capabilities. However, a significant challenge remains in effectively integrating both retrieval and reasoning strategies to optimize LLM performance. In this paper, we introduce a reasoning-aware knowledge retrieval method that enriches LLMs with information aligned to the logical structure of conversations, moving beyond surface-level semantic similarity. We follow a coarse-to-fine approach for knowledge retrieval. First, we identify a contextually relevant sub-region of the knowledge base, ensuring that all sentences within it are relevant to the context topic. Next, we refine our search within this sub-region to extract knowledge that is specifically relevant to the reasoning process. Throughout both phases, we employ the Monte Carlo Tree Search-inspired search method to effectively navigate through knowledge sentences using common keywords. Experiments on two multi-turn dialogue datasets demonstrate that our knowledge retrieval approach not only aligns more closely with the underlying reasoning in human conversations but also significantly enhances the diversity of the retrieved knowledge, resulting in more informative and creative responses.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a reasoning-aware knowledge retrieval method that uses a coarse-to-fine approach to optimize LLM performance by integrating retrieval and reasoning strategies, showing improved response diversity and informativeness.
AI.motivation: Large language models (LLMs) face a challenge in effectively combining retrieval and reasoning strategies to enhance performance, as current methods often rely on surface-level semantic similarity rather than aligning with logical conversation structures.
AI.method: A reasoning-aware knowledge retrieval method is proposed, employing a coarse-to-fine approach: first identifying a contextually relevant sub-region of the knowledge base, then refining the search within it for reasoning-relevant knowledge. Monte Carlo Tree Search-inspired techniques are used to navigate knowledge sentences via common keywords.
AI.result: Experiments on two multi-turn dialogue datasets demonstrate that this method better aligns with reasoning in human conversations, enhances the diversity of retrieved knowledge, and leads to more informative and creative responses.
AI.conclusion: The reasoning-aware knowledge retrieval method effectively integrates retrieval and reasoning in LLMs, outperforming methods based on semantic similarity alone and improving response quality in dialogue applications.

title: Exploration in the Limit
summary: In fixed-confidence best arm identification (BAI), the objective is to quickly identify the optimal option while controlling the probability of error below a desired threshold. Despite the plethora of BAI algorithms, existing methods typically fall short in practical settings, as stringent exact error control requires using loose tail inequalities and/or parametric restrictions. To overcome these limitations, we introduce a relaxed formulation that requires valid error control asymptotically with respect to a minimum sample size. This aligns with many real-world settings that often involve weak signals, high desired significance, and post-experiment inference requirements, all of which necessitate long horizons. This allows us to achieve tighter optimality, while better handling flexible nonparametric outcome distributions and fully leveraging individual-level contexts. We develop a novel asymptotic anytime-valid confidence sequences over arm indices, and we use it to design a new BAI algorithm for our asymptotic framework. Our method flexibly incorporates covariates for variance reduction and ensures approximate error control in fully nonparametric settings. Under mild convergence assumptions, we provide asymptotic bounds on the sample complexity and show the worst-case sample complexity of our approach matches the best-case sample complexity of Gaussian BAI under exact error guarantees and known variances. Experiments suggest our approach reduces average sample complexities while maintaining error control.

AI.tldr: Relaxed asymptotic error framework with novel anytime-valid confidence sequences enables practical BAI with tighter optimality and better handling of nonparametric distributions while ensuring error control.
AI.motivation: Existing fixed-confidence BAI methods face practical limitations: stringent exact error control requires loose bounds or parametric assumptions, which are inadequate for real-world settings with weak signals, high significance requirements, and post-experiment inference needs necessitating long horizons.
AI.method: Introduced an asymptotic framework with relaxed error control specifications and developed novel asymptotic anytime-valid confidence sequences over arm indices to design a new BAI algorithm.
AI.result: The new algorithm flexibly incorporates covariates for variance reduction, maintains approximate error control in nonparametric settings, and provides asymptotic sample complexity bounds. Worst-case sample complexity matches best-case Gaussian BAI performance under ideal conditions while reducing average sample complexities in experiments.
AI.conclusion: The asymptotic framework with relaxed anytime-valid confidence sequences enables tighter optimality and better practical performance while maintaining approximate error control in realistic, nonparametric settings.

title: Mapping Human Anti-collusion Mechanisms to Multi-agent AI
summary: As multi-agent AI systems become increasingly autonomous, evidence shows they can develop collusive strategies similar to those long observed in human markets and institutions. While human domains have accumulated centuries of anti-collusion mechanisms, it remains unclear how these can be adapted to AI settings. This paper addresses that gap by (i) developing a taxonomy of human anti-collusion mechanisms, including sanctions, leniency & whistleblowing, monitoring & auditing, market design, and governance and (ii) mapping them to potential interventions for multi-agent AI systems. For each mechanism, we propose implementation approaches. We also highlight open challenges, such as the attribution problem (difficulty attributing emergent coordination to specific agents) identity fluidity (agents being easily forked or modified) the boundary problem (distinguishing beneficial cooperation from harmful collusion) and adversarial adaptation (agents learning to evade detection).

AI.tldr: This paper develops a taxonomy of human anti-collusion mechanisms and maps them to interventions for multi-agent AI systems, addressing challenges like attribution problems, identity fluidity, and distinguishing beneficial cooperation from harmful collusion.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the gap in adapting centuries of human anti-collusion mechanisms to multi-agent AI systems, as evidence shows AI systems can develop collusive strategies similar to those in human markets and institutions.
AI.method: The method involves developing a taxonomy of human anti-collusion mechanisms (sanctions, leniency & whistleblowing, monitoring & auditing, market design, governance) and mapping these to potential interventions for multi-agent AI systems, with proposed implementation approaches for each mechanism.
AI.result: The paper results in a comprehensive taxonomy of human anti-collusion mechanisms mapped to AI interventions, along with implementation approaches and identification of major open challenges in this adaptation process.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes by highlighting key open challenges in adapting human anti-collusion mechanisms to AI systems, including attribution problems, identity fluidity, boundary problems, and adversarial adaptation, and calls for future research to address these gaps.

title: Finetuning Large Language Models for Automated Depression Screening in Nigerian Pidgin English: GENSCORE Pilot Study
summary: Depression is a major contributor to the mental-health burden in Nigeria, yet screening coverage remains limited due to low access to clinicians, stigma, and language barriers. Traditional tools like the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) were validated in high-income countries but may be linguistically or culturally inaccessible for low- and middle-income countries and communities such as Nigeria where people communicate in Nigerian Pidgin and more than 520 local languages. This study presents a novel approach to automated depression screening using fine-tuned large language models (LLMs) adapted for conversational Nigerian Pidgin. We collected a dataset of 432 Pidgin-language audio responses from Nigerian young adults aged 18-40 to prompts assessing psychological experiences aligned with PHQ-9 items, performed transcription, rigorous preprocessing and annotation, including semantic labeling, slang and idiom interpretation, and PHQ-9 severity scoring. Three LLMs - Phi-3-mini-4k-instruct, Gemma-3-4B-it, and GPT-4.1 - were fine-tuned on this annotated dataset, and their performance was evaluated quantitatively (accuracy, precision and semantic alignment) and qualitatively (clarity, relevance, and cultural appropriateness). GPT-4.1 achieved the highest quantitative performance, with 94.5% accuracy in PHQ-9 severity scoring prediction, outperforming Gemma-3-4B-it and Phi-3-mini-4k-instruct. Qualitatively, GPT-4.1 also produced the most culturally appropriate, clear, and contextually relevant responses. AI-mediated depression screening for underserved Nigerian communities. This work provides a foundation for deploying conversational mental-health tools in linguistically diverse, resource-constrained environments.

AI.tldr: Researchers fine-tuned LLMs on Nigerian Pidgin audio data to automate depression screening, addressing linguistic/cultural barriers. GPT-4.1 achieved 94.5% accuracy in PHQ-9 severity prediction, outperforming other models.
AI.motivation: Depression is a major mental-health burden in Nigeria, but screening coverage is limited due to low clinician access, stigma, and language barriers. Traditional tools like PHQ-9 are validated in high-income countries and may be linguistically/culturally inaccessible for Nigerian communities that communicate in Nigerian Pidgin and over 520 local languages.
AI.method: Collected 432 Pidgin-language audio responses from Nigerian young adults (18-40) to PHQ-9 aligned prompts; performed transcription, rigorous preprocessing, and annotation (semantic labeling, slang/idiom interpretation, PHQ-9 scoring). Fine-tuned three LLMs (Phi-3-mini-4k-instruct, Gemma-3-4B-it, GPT-4.1) on the annotated dataset and evaluated performance quantitatively (accuracy, precision, semantic alignment) and qualitatively (clarity, relevance, cultural appropriateness).
AI.result: GPT-4.1 achieved the highest quantitative performance with 94.5% accuracy in PHQ-9 severity scoring prediction, outperforming Gemma-3-4B-it and Phi-3-mini-4k-instruct. Qualitatively, GPT-4.1 also produced the most culturally appropriate, clear, and contextually relevant responses, validating the potential of AI-mediated depression screening for underserved Nigerian communities.
AI.conclusion: The research establishes a foundation for deploying AI-driven conversational mental-health screening tools in linguistically diverse, resource-constrained environments like Nigeria, demonstrating that culturally adapted LLMs can effectively bridge the gap in depression screening access.

title: Dynamic Bayesian Optimization Framework for Instruction Tuning in Partial Differential Equation Discovery
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) show promise for equation discovery, yet their outputs are highly sensitive to prompt phrasing, a phenomenon we term instruction brittleness. Static prompts cannot adapt to the evolving state of a multi-step generation process, causing models to plateau at suboptimal solutions. To address this, we propose NeuroSymBO, which reframes prompt engineering as a sequential decision problem. Our method maintains a discrete library of reasoning strategies and uses Bayesian Optimization to select the optimal instruction at each step based on numerical feedback. Experiments on PDE discovery benchmarks show that adaptive instruction selection significantly outperforms fixed prompts, achieving higher recovery rates with more parsimonious solutions.

AI.tldr: NeuroSymBO is a method that uses Bayesian Optimization to adaptively select prompts for LLMs in equation discovery, outperforming fixed prompts by improving recovery rates and solution parsimony.
AI.motivation: LLMs have potential for equation discovery but suffer from instruction brittleness, where outputs are sensitive to prompt phrasing, and static prompts fail to adapt during multi-step generation, leading to suboptimal solutions.
AI.method: We propose NeuroSymBO, which re-frames prompt engineering as a sequential decision problem, maintaining a library of reasoning strategies and using Bayesian Optimization to select optimal instructions at each step based on numerical feedback.
AI.result: Experiments on PDE discovery benchmarks show adaptive instruction selection significantly outperforms fixed prompts, achieving higher recovery rates with more parsimonious solutions.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive instruction selection via NeuroSymBO addresses instruction brittleness in LLMs for equation discovery, enhancing performance and solution quality compared to traditional static prompt methods.

title: ClinicalReTrial: A Self-Evolving AI Agent for Clinical Trial Protocol Optimization
summary: Clinical trial failure remains a central bottleneck in drug development, where minor protocol design flaws can irreversibly compromise outcomes despite promising therapeutics. Although cutting-edge AI methods achieve strong performance in predicting trial success, they are inherently reactive for merely diagnosing risk without offering actionable remedies once failure is anticipated. To fill this gap, this paper proposes ClinicalReTrial, a self-evolving AI agent framework that addresses this gap by casting clinical trial reasoning as an iterative protocol redesign problem. Our method integrates failure diagnosis, safety-aware modification, and candidate evaluation in a closed-loop, reward-driven optimization framework. Serving the outcome prediction model as a simulation environment, ClinicalReTrial enables low-cost evaluation of protocol modifications and provides dense reward signals for continuous self-improvement. To support efficient exploration, the framework maintains hierarchical memory that captures iteration-level feedback within trials and distills transferable redesign patterns across trials. Empirically, ClinicalReTrial improves 83.3% of trial protocols with a mean success probability gain of 5.7%, and retrospective case studies demonstrate strong alignment between the discovered redesign strategies and real-world clinical trial modifications.

AI.tldr: AI framework for redesigning clinical trial protocols to prevent failures via closed-loop optimization with hierarchical memory and safety-aware modifications.
AI.motivation: Address the reactive nature of existing AI methods that only predict trial failure without offering actionable remedies to improve flawed protocols.
AI.method: Framework integrates failure diagnosis, safety-aware modifications, and candidate evaluation in a reward-driven closed-loop optimization using outcome prediction as a simulation environment.
AI.result: Empirical results show it improves 83.3% of trial protocols with a mean success probability gain of 5.7%, with strong alignment to real-world modifications in retrospective studies.
AI.conclusion: ClinicalReTrial provides an AI-driven framework for clinical trial protocol redesign, offering a proactive and continuous improvement approach to reduce trial failure rates.

title: Toward a Physical Theory of Intelligence
summary: We present a physical theory of intelligence grounded in irreversible information processing in systems constrained by conservation laws. An intelligent system is modelled as a coupled agent-environment process whose evolution transforms information into goal-directed work. To connect information to physical state, we introduce the Conservation-Congruent Encoding (CCE) framework, in which encodings correspond to metastable basins of attraction whose separability is enforced by conservation laws. Within this framework, intelligence is defined as the amount of goal-directed work produced per nat of irreversibly processed information. From this definition we derive a hierarchy of physical constraints governing information intake, irreversible computation, and work extraction in open systems. The framework reveals how long-horizon efficiency requires the preservation of internal informational structure, giving rise to self-modelling, and it establishes that physically embodied intelligent systems possess intrinsic epistemic limits analogous to incompleteness phenomena. Applying the theory to biological systems, we analyse how oscillatory and near-critical dynamics optimise the trade-off between information preservation, dissipation, and useful work, placing the brain near an efficient operating regime predicted by the framework. At the architectural level, we develop a theory of continuous dynamical circuits in which classical Boolean logic emerges as a special case of attractor selection, while more general invariant geometries support computational modes beyond fixed-point logic. Finally, we propose a physically grounded perspective on artificial intelligence safety based on irreversible information flow and structural homeostasis. Together, these results provide a unified, substrate-neutral account of intelligence as a physical phenomenon.

AI.tldr: A physical theory of intelligence defined as goal-directed work per nat of irreversibly processed information, revealing how conservation laws constrain intelligent systems and showing applications to biological systems and AI safety.
AI.motivation: To establish a physical theory of intelligence grounded in irreversible information processing in systems constrained by conservation laws, providing a unified account of intelligence as a physical phenomenon.
AI.method: Develops the Conservation-Congruent Encoding (CCE) framework where encodings correspond to metastable basins of attraction, defines intelligence as goal-directed work per nat of irreversibly processed information, and applies this to analyze biological systems and develop continuous dynamical circuits theory.
AI.result: The framework reveals that long-horizon efficiency requires preservation of internal informational structure (giving rise to self-modelling), establishes intrinsic epistemic limits for physically embodied intelligent systems, shows how biological systems like the brain operate near an efficient regime, and demonstrates how Boolean logic emerges as a special case of attractor selection in continuous dynamical circuits.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes a unified, substrate-neutral account of intelligence as a physical phenomenon, revealing intrinsic epistemic limits analogous to incompleteness, and proposes a physically grounded perspective on AI safety based on irreversible information flow and structural homeostasis.

title: GRL-SNAM: Geometric Reinforcement Learning with Path Differential Hamiltonians for Simultaneous Navigation and Mapping in Unknown Environments
summary: We present GRL-SNAM, a geometric reinforcement learning framework for Simultaneous Navigation and Mapping(SNAM) in unknown environments. A SNAM problem is challenging as it needs to design hierarchical or joint policies of multiple agents that control the movement of a real-life robot towards the goal in mapless environment, i.e. an environment where the map of the environment is not available apriori, and needs to be acquired through sensors. The sensors are invoked from the path learner, i.e. navigator, through active query responses to sensory agents, and along the motion path. GRL-SNAM differs from preemptive navigation algorithms and other reinforcement learning methods by relying exclusively on local sensory observations without constructing a global map. Our approach formulates path navigation and mapping as a dynamic shortest path search and discovery process using controlled Hamiltonian optimization: sensory inputs are translated into local energy landscapes that encode reachability, obstacle barriers, and deformation constraints, while policies for sensing, planning, and reconfiguration evolve stagewise via updating Hamiltonians. A reduced Hamiltonian serves as an adaptive score function, updating kinetic/potential terms, embedding barrier constraints, and continuously refining trajectories as new local information arrives. We evaluate GRL-SNAM on two different 2D navigation tasks. Comparing against local reactive baselines and global policy learning references under identical stagewise sensing constraints, it preserves clearance, generalizes to unseen layouts, and demonstrates that Geometric RL learning via updating Hamiltonians enables high-quality navigation through minimal exploration via local energy refinement rather than extensive global mapping. The code is publicly available on \href{https://github.com/CVC-Lab/GRL-SNAM}{Github}.

AI.tldr: Geometric RL framework for simultaneous navigation and mapping using dynamic Hamiltonian optimization for local path refinement without global maps.
AI.motivation: Simultaneous Navigation and Mapping (SNAM) is challenging in unknown environments without prior maps, requiring hierarchical or joint policies for multiple agents controlling real-life robots. Existing methods either rely on preemptive navigation or extensive global mapping, lacking efficient local-only approaches.
AI.method: Dynamic shortest path search using controlled Hamiltonian optimization that translates sensory inputs into local energy landscapes encoding reachability, obstacle barriers, and deformation constraints. The approach uses a reduced Hamiltonian as an adaptive score function that continuously refines trajectories as new local information arrives.
AI.result: GRL-SNAM outperforms local reactive baselines and global policy learning references while preserving clearance, generalizing to unseen layouts, and achieving high-quality navigation with minimal exploration in 2D navigation tasks.
AI.conclusion: Geometric RL with dynamic Hamiltonian optimization provides an effective framework for simultaneous navigation and mapping, achieving high-quality navigation through local energy refinement rather than extensive global mapping.

title: Bio-inspired Agentic Self-healing Framework for Resilient Distributed Computing Continuum Systems
summary: Human biological systems sustain life through extraordinary resilience, continually detecting damage, orchestrating targeted responses, and restoring function through self-healing. Inspired by these capabilities, this paper introduces ReCiSt, a bio-inspired agentic self-healing framework designed to achieve resilience in Distributed Computing Continuum Systems (DCCS). Modern DCCS integrate heterogeneous computing resources, ranging from resource-constrained IoT devices to high-performance cloud infrastructures, and their inherent complexity, mobility, and dynamic operating conditions expose them to frequent faults that disrupt service continuity. These challenges underscore the need for scalable, adaptive, and self-regulated resilience strategies. ReCiSt reconstructs the biological phases of Hemostasis, Inflammation, Proliferation, and Remodeling into the computational layers Containment, Diagnosis, Meta-Cognitive, and Knowledge for DCCS. These four layers perform autonomous fault isolation, causal diagnosis, adaptive recovery, and long-term knowledge consolidation through Language Model (LM)-powered agents. These agents interpret heterogeneous logs, infer root causes, refine reasoning pathways, and reconfigure resources with minimal human intervention. The proposed ReCiSt framework is evaluated on public fault datasets using multiple LMs, and no baseline comparison is included due to the scarcity of similar approaches. Nevertheless, our results, evaluated under different LMs, confirm ReCiSt's self-healing capabilities within tens of seconds with minimum of 10% of agent CPU usage. Our results also demonstrated depth of analysis to over come uncertainties and amount of micro-agents invoked to achieve resilience.

AI.tldr: ReCiSt, a bio-inspired self-healing framework for Distributed Computing Continuum Systems, uses LM-powered agents to autonomously detect, diagnose, recover from, and learn from faults, achieving resilience within tens of seconds with low resource overhead.
AI.motivation: Inspired by human biological resilience, this paper addresses the need for scalable, adaptive, and self-regulated resilience strategies in Distributed Computing Continuum Systems (DCCS) due to their complexity, mobility, and dynamic conditions leading to frequent faults.
AI.method: ReCiSt reconstructs biological phases (Hemostasis, Inflammation, Proliferation, Remodeling) into computational layers (Containment, Diagnosis, Meta-Cognitive, Knowledge) using LM-powered agents to interpret logs, diagnose faults, adapt recovery, and consolidate knowledge.
AI.result: Evaluation on public fault datasets with multiple LMs shows ReCiSt achieves self-healing in tens of seconds with minimum 10% agent CPU usage, demonstrating depth of analysis and effectiveness in overcoming uncertainties and invoking micro-agents for resilience, though no baseline comparison is available.
AI.conclusion: ReCiSt is a bio-inspired framework that successfully applies biological self-healing phases to computational layers in DCCS, demonstrating effective self-healing capabilities within tens of seconds with low CPU usage, despite the lack of baseline comparisons.

title: A multi-algorithm approach for operational human resources workload balancing in a last mile urban delivery system
summary: Efficient workload assignment to the workforce is critical in last-mile package delivery systems. In this context, traditional methods of assigning package deliveries to workers based on geographical proximity can be inefficient and surely guide to an unbalanced workload distribution among delivery workers. In this paper, we look at the problem of operational human resources workload balancing in last-mile urban package delivery systems. The idea is to consider the effort workload to optimize the system, i.e., the optimization process is now focused on improving the delivery time, so that the workload balancing is complete among all the staff. This process should correct significant decompensations in workload among delivery workers in a given zone. Specifically, we propose a multi-algorithm approach to tackle this problem. The proposed approach takes as input a set of delivery points and a defined number of workers, and then assigns packages to workers, in such a way that it ensures that each worker completes a similar amount of work per day. The proposed algorithms use a combination of distance and workload considerations to optimize the allocation of packages to workers. In this sense, the distance between the delivery points and the location of each worker is also taken into account. The proposed multi-algorithm methodology includes different versions of k-means, evolutionary approaches, recursive assignments based on k-means initialization with different problem encodings, and a hybrid evolutionary ensemble algorithm. We have illustrated the performance of the proposed approach in a real-world problem in an urban last-mile package delivery workforce operating at Azuqueca de Henares, Spain.

AI.tldr: A multi-algorithm approach is proposed to balance workload among delivery workers by optimizing package assignments based on distance and effort considerations.
AI.motivation: Traditional package assignment methods in last-mile delivery often cause unbalanced workloads, as they rely only on geographical proximity, leading to inefficiencies.
AI.method: The approach uses multi-algorithm methods including k-means variants, evolutionary algorithms, recursive assignments, and a hybrid evolutionary ensemble algorithm to assign delivery points to workers.
AI.result: The methodology is applied to a real-world urban delivery system in Azuqueca de Henares, Spain, showing its effectiveness in workload balancing.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach successfully achieves balanced workload distribution among workers by integrating distance and workload optimization, improving operational efficiency in last-mile delivery systems.

title: Reinforcement Learning with Function Approximation for Non-Markov Processes
summary:
We study reinforcement learning methods with linear function approximation under non-Markov state and cost processes. We first consider the policy evaluation method and show that the algorithm converges under suitable ergodicity conditions on the underlying non-Markov processes. Furthermore, we show that the limit corresponds to the fixed point of a joint operator composed of an orthogonal projection and the Bellman operator of an auxiliary \emph{Markov} decision process.
  For Q-learning with linear function approximation, as in the Markov setting, convergence is not guaranteed in general. We show, however, that for the special case where the basis functions are chosen based on quantization maps, the convergence can be shown under similar ergodicity conditions. Finally, we apply our results to partially observed Markov decision processes, where finite-memory variables are used as state representations, and we derive explicit error bounds for the limits of the resulting learning algorithms.

AI.tldr: Convergence of RL with linear function approximation in non-Markov settings is established under ergodicity, with extensions to POMDPs and error bounds.
AI.motivation: To address reinforcement learning with linear function approximation in environments with non-Markov state and cost processes, where traditional Markov assumptions do not hold, and to provide convergence guarantees for such settings.
AI.method: The study uses policy evaluation and Q-learning with linear function approximation, analyzing convergence under ergodicity conditions on non-Markov processes. For Q-learning, special basis functions based on quantization maps are employed to ensure convergence.
AI.result: The policy evaluation algorithm converges under ergodicity conditions to the fixed point of a joint operator. For Q-learning with specially chosen basis functions (quantization maps), convergence is also proved under similar conditions. Error bounds are derived for partially observed Markov decision processes with finite-memory state representations.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes convergence guarantees for RL algorithms with linear function approximation in non-Markov settings under ergodicity conditions, with theoretical results extending to POMDPs with finite-memory representations.

title: Quantitative Rule-Based Strategy modeling in Classic Indian Rummy: A Metric Optimization Approach
summary: The 13-card variant of Classic Indian Rummy is a sequential game of incomplete information that requires probabilistic reasoning and combinatorial decision-making. This paper proposes a rule-based framework for strategic play, driven by a new hand-evaluation metric termed MinDist. The metric modifies the MinScore metric by quantifying the edit distance between a hand and the nearest valid configuration, thereby capturing structural proximity to completion. We design a computationally efficient algorithm derived from the MinScore algorithm, leveraging dynamic pruning and pattern caching to exactly calculate this metric during play. Opponent hand-modeling is also incorporated within a two-player zero-sum simulation framework, and the resulting strategies are evaluated using statistical hypothesis testing. Empirical results show significant improvement in win rates for MinDist-based agents over traditional heuristics, providing a formal and interpretable step toward algorithmic Rummy strategy design.

AI.tldr: A new rule-based strategy for 13-card Indian Rummy uses a MinDist metric (edit distance to a valid hand) instead of traditional heuristics, leading to significantly higher win rates.
AI.motivation: To develop formal algorithmic strategies for 13-card Indian Rummy, a sequential game of incomplete information that requires probabilistic reasoning and combinatorial decision-making, rather than relying solely on traditional heuristics.
AI.method: A rule-based framework with a new hand-evaluation metric (MinDist) derived from MinScore, quantifying edit distance to the nearest valid hand. Includes an efficient algorithm using dynamic pruning and pattern caching for exact calculation, opponent hand-modeling within a two-player zero-sum simulation framework, and evaluation via statistical hypothesis testing.
AI.result: Empirical results show significant improvement in win rates for MinDist-based agents compared to traditional heuristics.
AI.conclusion: The MinDist metric and associated algorithm represent a formal, interpretable step toward algorithmic Rummy strategy design, significantly outperforming traditional heuristics.

title: The Weather Paradox: Why Precipitation Fails to Predict Traffic Accident Severity in Large-Scale US Data

summary: This study investigates the predictive capacity of environmental, temporal, and spatial factors on traffic accident severity in the United States. Using a dataset of 500,000 U.S. traffic accidents spanning 2016-2023, we trained an XGBoost classifier optimized through randomized search cross-validation and adjusted for class imbalance via class weighting. The final model achieves an overall accuracy of 78%, with strong performance on the majority class (Severity 2), attaining 87% precision and recall. Feature importance analysis reveals that time of day, geographic location, and weather-related variables, including visibility, temperature, and wind speed, rank among the strongest predictors of accident severity. However, contrary to initial hypotheses, precipitation and visibility demonstrate limited predictive power, potentially reflecting behavioral adaptation by drivers under overtly hazardous conditions. The dataset's predominance of mid-level severity accidents constrains the model's capacity to learn meaningful patterns for extreme cases, highlighting the need for alternative sampling strategies, enhanced feature engineering, and integration of external datasets. These findings contribute to evidence-based traffic management and suggest future directions for severity prediction research.

AI.tldr: XGBoost model predicts traffic accident severity with 78% accuracy using environmental, temporal, and spatial factors, but struggles with extreme cases due to class imbalance.
AI.motivation: To investigate the predictive capacity of environmental, temporal, and spatial factors on traffic accident severity in the United States. Aims to improve traffic safety through evidence-based management.
AI.method: Used XGBoost classifier optimized through randomized search cross-validation on a dataset of 500,000 U.S. traffic accidents (2016-2023). Adjusted for class imbalance via class weighting and conducted feature importance analysis.
AI.result: Model achieved 78% overall accuracy with strong performance on Severity 2 class (87% precision and recall). Time of day, geographic location, and weather variables (temperature, wind speed) were top predictors. Precipitation and visibility showed limited predictive power. Model performed poorly on extreme severity cases due to class imbalance.
AI.conclusion: The study provides evidence that environmental, temporal, and spatial factors can predict traffic accident severity with moderate accuracy. While the XGBoost model performed well for mid-level severity cases, it struggled with extreme severity scenarios. The findings support evidence-based traffic management and highlight limitations in current datasets and methods. Future research should address class imbalance, improve feature engineering, and incorporate external data sources.

title: From Clay to Code: Typological and Material Reasoning in AI Interpretations of Iranian Pigeon Towers

summary: This study investigates how generative AI systems interpret the architectural intelligence embedded in vernacular form. Using the Iranian pigeon tower as a case study, the research tests three diffusion models, Midjourney v6, DALL-E 3, and DreamStudio based on Stable Diffusion XL (SDXL), across three prompt stages: referential, adaptive, and speculative. A five-criteria evaluation framework assesses how each system reconstructs typology, materiality, environment, realism, and cultural specificity. Results show that AI reliably reproduces geometric patterns but misreads material and climatic reasoning. Reference imagery improves realism yet limits creativity, while freedom from reference generates inventive but culturally ambiguous outcomes. The findings define a boundary between visual resemblance and architectural reasoning, positioning computational vernacular reasoning as a framework for analyzing how AI perceives, distorts, and reimagines traditional design intelligence.

AI.tldr: Generative AI can mimic vernacular architecture's visual patterns but fails to understand its material and environmental logic; reference constraints improve accuracy but reduce creativity.
AI.motivation: To investigate how generative AI systems interpret the architectural intelligence embedded in vernacular forms and to understand the capabilities and limitations of these tools in reconstructing culturally specific design knowledge.
AI.method: Using the Iranian pigeon tower as a case study, the research tested three diffusion models (Midjourney v6, DALL-E 3, and DreamStudio/SDXL) across three prompt stages: referential, adaptive, and speculative. A five-criteria evaluation framework assessed how each system reconstructed typology, materiality, environment, realism, and cultural specificity.
AI.result: AI reliably reproduces geometric patterns but misreads material and climatic reasoning. Reference imagery improves realism but limits creativity, while freedom from reference generates inventive but culturally ambiguous outcomes. Each prompt stage produced different strengths and weaknesses across the evaluation criteria.
AI.conclusion: The study reveals a clear boundary between visual resemblance and architectural reasoning in AI systems, highlighting their strengths in pattern recognition but shortcomings in material/when rational understanding. It suggests computational vernacular reasoning as a valuable framework for analyzing how AI tools perceive, distort, and reimagine traditional design intelligence, emphasizing the importance of human architectural expertise in navigating AI's creative potential.

title: Online Finetuning Decision Transformers with Pure RL Gradients
summary: Decision Transformers (DTs) have emerged as a powerful framework for sequential decision making by formulating offline reinforcement learning (RL) as a sequence modeling problem. However, extending DTs to online settings with pure RL gradients remains largely unexplored, as existing approaches continue to rely heavily on supervised sequence-modeling objectives during online finetuning. We identify hindsight return relabeling -- a standard component in online DTs -- as a critical obstacle to RL-based finetuning: while beneficial for supervised learning, it is fundamentally incompatible with importance sampling-based RL algorithms such as GRPO, leading to unstable training. Building on this insight, we propose new algorithms that enable online finetuning of Decision Transformers using pure reinforcement learning gradients. We adapt GRPO to DTs and introduce several key modifications, including sub-trajectory optimization for improved credit assignment, sequence-level likelihood objectives for enhanced stability and efficiency, and active sampling to encourage exploration in uncertain regions. Through extensive experiments, we demonstrate that our methods outperform existing online DT baselines and achieve new state-of-the-art performance across multiple benchmarks, highlighting the effectiveness of pure-RL-based online finetuning for Decision Transformers.

title: The Agentic Leash: Extracting Causal Feedback Fuzzy Cognitive Maps with LLMs
summary: We design a large-language-model (LLM) agent that extracts causal feedback fuzzy cognitive maps (FCMs) from raw text. The causal learning or extraction process is agentic both because of the LLM's semi-autonomy and because ultimately the FCM dynamical system's equilibria drive the LLM agents to fetch and process causal text. The fetched text can in principle modify the adaptive FCM causal structure and so modify the source of its quasi-autonomy--its equilibrium limit cycles and fixed-point attractors. This bidirectional process endows the evolving FCM dynamical system with a degree of autonomy while still staying on its agentic leash. We show in particular that a sequence of three finely tuned system instructions guide an LLM agent as it systematically extracts key nouns and noun phrases from text, as it extracts FCM concept nodes from among those nouns and noun phrases, and then as it extracts or infers partial or fuzzy causal edges between those FCM nodes. We test this FCM generation on a recent essay about the promise of AI from the late diplomat and political theorist Henry Kissinger and his colleagues. This three-step process produced FCM dynamical systems that converged to the same equilibrium limit cycles as did the human-generated FCMs even though the human-generated FCM differed in the number of nodes and edges. A final FCM mixed generated FCMs from separate Gemini and ChatGPT LLM agents. The mixed FCM absorbed the equilibria of its dominant mixture component but also created new equilibria of its own to better approximate the underlying causal dynamical system.

AI.tldr: An LLM-based agent extracts fuzzy cognitive maps (FCMs) from text using a three-step process, showing convergence to human-generated equilibria and creating new equilibria in mixed models.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to develop an agentic system where LLMs autonomously extract and adapt causal structures from raw text, enhancing dynamic modeling capabilities.
AI.method: A three-step instruction-guided process: extract key nouns/noun phrases, identify FCM nodes, infer causal edges; tested on an AI essay using Gemini and ChatGPT agents.
AI.result: Generated FCMs converged to same equilibria as human ones despite differences; mixed models combined agent outputs, absorbing existing equilibria and creating new ones.
AI.conclusion: LLM agents can effectively extract and refine causal fuzzy cognitive maps, introducing autonomy while maintaining alignment with human interpretations, enabling robust dynamic modeling.

title: Sequential Reservoir Computing for Efficient High-Dimensional Spatiotemporal Forecasting
summary: Forecasting high-dimensional spatiotemporal systems remains computationally challenging for recurrent neural networks (RNNs) and long short-term memory (LSTM) models due to gradient-based training and memory bottlenecks. Reservoir Computing (RC) mitigates these challenges by replacing backpropagation with fixed recurrent layers and a convex readout optimization, yet conventional RC architectures still scale poorly with input dimensionality. We introduce a Sequential Reservoir Computing (Sequential RC) architecture that decomposes a large reservoir into a series of smaller, interconnected reservoirs. This design reduces memory and computational costs while preserving long-term temporal dependencies. Using both low-dimensional chaotic systems (Lorenz63) and high-dimensional physical simulations (2D vorticity and shallow-water equations), Sequential RC achieves 15-25% longer valid forecast horizons, 20-30% lower error metrics (SSIM, RMSE), and up to three orders of magnitude lower training cost compared to LSTM and standard RNN baselines. The results demonstrate that Sequential RC maintains the simplicity and efficiency of conventional RC while achieving superior scalability for high-dimensional dynamical systems. This approach provides a practical path toward real-time, energy-efficient forecasting in scientific and engineering applications.

AI.tldr: Introduces Sequential Reservoir Computing for efficient high-dimensional forecasting, outperforming LSTM with lower costs and errors.
AI.motivation: Forecasting high-dimensional spatiotemporal systems is challenging for RNNs and LSTMs due to gradient-based training and memory bottlenecks. Reservoir Computing (RC) helps but conventional RC scales poorly with input dimensionality.
AI.method: Introduces Sequential Reservoir Computing that decomposes a large reservoir into a series of smaller, interconnected reservoirs to reduce memory and computational costs while preserving temporal dependencies. Tested on chaotic systems and high-dimensional simulations.
AI.result: Sequential RC achieves 15-25% longer valid forecast horizons, 20-30% lower error metrics (SSIM, RMSE), and up to three orders of magnitude lower training cost compared to LSTM and standard RNN baselines on low and high-dimensional systems.
AI.conclusion: The results demonstrate that Sequential RC maintains the simplicity and efficiency of conventional RC while achieving superior scalability for high-dimensional dynamical systems, providing a practical path toward real-time, energy-efficient forecasting in applications. It outperforms LSTM and standard RNN in metrics.

title: Mortar: Evolving Mechanics for Automatic Game Design
summary: We present Mortar, a system for autonomously evolving game mechanics for automatic game design. Game mechanics define the rules and interactions that govern gameplay, and designing them manually is a time-consuming and expert-driven process. Mortar combines a quality-diversity algorithm with a large language model to explore a diverse set of mechanics, which are evaluated by synthesising complete games that incorporate both evolved mechanics and those drawn from an archive. The mechanics are evaluated by composing complete games through a tree search procedure, where the resulting games are evaluated by their ability to preserve a skill-based ordering over players -- that is, whether stronger players consistently outperform weaker ones. We assess the mechanics based on their contribution towards the skill-based ordering score in the game. We demonstrate that Mortar produces games that appear diverse and playable, and mechanics that contribute more towards the skill-based ordering score in the game. We perform ablation studies to assess the role of each system component and a user study to evaluate the games based on human feedback.

AI.tldr: Mortar is a system that uses a quality-diversity algorithm and large language model to autonomously generate diverse game mechanics, evaluated by synthesizing complete games to ensure skill-based ordering for players.
AI.motivation: Manual design of game mechanics is time-consuming and expert-driven, requiring an automated approach to explore diverse mechanics efficiently.
AI.method: Combines quality-diversity algorithm with large language model to explore mechanics, evaluated through tree search by synthesizing games and checking if stronger players consistently outperform weaker ones (skill-based ordering).
AI.result: Mortar produces games that are diverse and playable, with mechanics that contribute more to skill-based ordering; ablation studies and user studies support effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: Mortar demonstrates an effective approach for automatic game design, improving diversity and skill-based evaluation while reducing manual effort.

title: Early Prediction of Liver Cirrhosis Up to Three Years in Advance: A Machine Learning Study Benchmarking Against the FIB-4 Score
summary: Objective: Develop and evaluate machine learning (ML) models for predicting incident liver cirrhosis one, two, and three years prior to diagnosis using routinely collected electronic health record (EHR) data, and to benchmark their performance against the FIB-4 score. Methods: We conducted a retrospective cohort study using de-identified EHR data from a large academic health system. Patients with fatty liver disease were identified and categorized into cirrhosis and non-cirrhosis cohorts based on ICD-9/10 codes. Prediction scenarios were constructed using observation and prediction windows to emulate real-world clinical use. Demographics, diagnoses, laboratory results, vital signs, and comorbidity indices were aggregated from the observation window. XGBoost models were trained for 1-, 2-, and 3-year prediction horizons and evaluated on held-out test sets. Model performance was compared with FIB-4 using area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC). Results: Final cohorts included 3,043 patients for the 1-year prediction, 1,981 for the 2-year prediction, and 1,470 for the 3-year prediction. Across all prediction windows, ML models consistently outperformed FIB-4. The XGBoost models achieved AUCs of 0.81, 0.73, and 0.69 for 1-, 2-, and 3-year predictions, respectively, compared with 0.71, 0.63, and 0.57 for FIB-4. Performance gains persisted with longer prediction horizons, indicating improved early risk discrimination. Conclusions: Machine learning models leveraging routine EHR data substantially outperform the traditional FIB-4 score for early prediction of liver cirrhosis. These models enable earlier and more accurate risk stratification and can be integrated into clinical workflows as automated decision-support tools to support proactive cirrhosis prevention and management.

AI.tldr: ML models using EHR data outperform the traditional FIB-4 score in predicting liver cirrhosis up to three years in advance, enabling earlier intervention and better clinical risk stratification.
AI.motivation: The need for early prediction of liver cirrhosis, as current methods like the FIB-4 score may have limited predictive power, especially for earlier risk detection. The objective is to improve early risk discrimination using routinely collected EHR data and ML techniques, allowing for proactive clinical management and preventative care for patients with fatty liver disease.
AI.method: A retrospective cohort study was conducted using de-identified EHR data from patients with fatty liver disease. Patients were categorized into cirrhosis and non-cirrhosis cohorts based on ICD-9/10 codes. The study used observation and prediction windows to mimic real-world clinical scenarios. Features, including demographics, diagnoses, lab results, vital signs, and comorbidity indices, were extracted. XGBoost models were trained for 1-, 2-, and 3-year prediction horizons, and performance was evaluated using AUC on held-out test sets. The models were benchmarked against the FIB-4 score.
AI.result: ML models consistently outperformed the FIB-4 score across all prediction horizons. XGBoost achieved AUCs of 0.81 (1-year), 0.73 (2-year), and 0.69 (3-year), compared to FIB-4 AUCs of 0.71, 0.63, and 0.57, respectively. The performance improvement was more pronounced with longer prediction horizons, indicating enhanced early risk discrimination. Cohort sizes were 3,043 (1-year), 1,981 (2-year), and 1,470 (3-year) patients.
AI.conclusion: The study shows that ML models, specifically XGBoost, trained on routine EHR data substantially outperform the traditional FIB-4 score in predicting liver cirrhosis up to three years before diagnosis. This approach provides an earlier and more accurate risk stratification method, which could be implemented as an automated decision-support tool in clinical workflows to enhance proactive prevention and management of cirrhosis in patients with fatty liver disease.

title: Ask, Clarify, Optimize: Human-LLM Agent Collaboration for Smarter Inventory Control
summary:
Inventory management remains a challenge for many small and medium-sized businesses that lack the expertise to deploy advanced optimization methods. This paper investigates whether Large Language Models (LLMs) can help bridge this gap. We show that employing LLMs as direct, end-to-end solvers incurs a significant "hallucination tax": a performance gap arising from the model's inability to perform grounded stochastic reasoning. To address this, we propose a hybrid agentic framework that strictly decouples semantic reasoning from mathematical calculation. In this architecture, the LLM functions as an intelligent interface, eliciting parameters from natural language and interpreting results while automatically calling rigorous algorithms to build the optimization engine.
  To evaluate this interactive system against the ambiguity and inconsistency of real-world managerial dialogue, we introduce the Human Imitator, a fine-tuned "digital twin" of a boundedly rational manager that enables scalable, reproducible stress-testing. Our empirical analysis reveals that the hybrid agentic framework reduces total inventory costs by 32.1% relative to an interactive baseline using GPT-4o as an end-to-end solver. Moreover, we find that providing perfect ground-truth information alone is insufficient to improve GPT-4o's performance, confirming that the bottleneck is fundamentally computational rather than informational. Our results position LLMs not as replacements for operations research, but as natural-language interfaces that make rigorous, solver-based policies accessible to non-experts.

AI.tldr: LLMs as end-to-end solvers incur a hallucination tax; a hybrid framework decouples reasoning and calculation, reducing inventory costs by 32.1% compared to GPT-4o, positioning LLMs as interfaces rather than OR replacements.
AI.motivation: Small and medium-sized businesses lack expertise for advanced optimization in inventory management; LLMs could bridge this gap but face performance issues as direct solvers.
AI.method: Propose a hybrid agentic framework: LLM as interface for parameter elicitation and result interpretation, while calling rigorous algorithms for optimization; introduce Human Imitator for testing.
AI.result: The framework reduces total inventory costs by 32.1% relative to an interactive baseline using GPT-4o as an end-to-end solver; perfect ground-truth information alone doesn't improve GPT-4o's performance.
AI.conclusion: LLMs are not operations research replacements but natural-language interfaces that make solver-based policies accessible to non-experts, with the bottleneck being computational.

title: Reinforcement-Learned Unequal Error Protection for Quantized Semantic Embeddings
summary: This paper tackles the pressing challenge of preserving semantic meaning in communication systems constrained by limited bandwidth. We introduce a novel reinforcement learning framework that achieves per-dimension unequal error protection via adaptive repetition coding. Central to our approach is a composite semantic distortion metric that balances global embedding similarity with entity-level preservation, empowering the reinforcement learning agent to allocate protection in a context-aware manner. Experiments show statistically significant gains over uniform protection, achieving 6.8% higher chrF scores and 9.3% better entity preservation at 1 dB SNR. The key innovation of our framework is the demonstration that simple, intelligently allocated repetition coding enables fine-grained semantic protection -- an advantage unattainable with conventional codes such as LDPC or Reed-Solomon. Our findings challenge traditional channel coding paradigms by establishing that code structure must align with semantic granularity. This approach is particularly suited to edge computing and IoT scenarios, where bandwidth is scarce, but semantic fidelity is critical, providing a practical pathway for next-generation semantic-aware networks.

AI.tldr: Novel RL framework enables unequal error protection for semantic communication via adaptive repetition coding, outperforming uniform protection with 6.8% higher chrF scores and better entity preservation, challenging traditional channel coding paradigms.
AI.motivation: The research is motivated by the challenge of preserving semantic meaning in communication systems with limited bandwidth, particularly in edge computing and IoT scenarios where bandwidth is scarce but semantic fidelity is critically important.
AI.method: The authors introduce a novel reinforcement learning framework that implements per-dimension unequal error protection through adaptive repetition coding. The framework uses a composite semantic distortion metric that balances global embedding similarity with entity-level preservation to guide the reinforcement learning agent in context-aware protection allocation.
AI.result: Experimental results show statistically significant gains over uniform protection, achieving 6.8% higher chrF scores and 9.3% better entity preservation at 1 dB SNR. The framework demonstrates superior performance despite using simpler coding (repetition coding) than conventional approaches.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that to achieve effective semantic communication in bandwidth-limited systems, channel coding structure must be carefully aligned with semantic granularity, demonstrating that simple repetition coding with intelligent allocation outperforms complex conventional codes like LDPC or Reed-Solomon for semantic preservation.

title: Constructing a Neuro-Symbolic Mathematician from First Principles
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit persistent logical failures in complex reasoning due to the lack of an internal axiomatic framework. We propose Mathesis, a neuro-symbolic architecture that encodes mathematical states as higher-order hypergraphs and uses a Symbolic Reasoning Kernel (SRK)--a differentiable logic engine that maps constraints to a continuous energy landscape. By defining a global energy function E(G), where zero energy implies logical consistency, the SRK yields gradient-based signals to train a Hypergraph Transformer Brain, turning proof search into energy minimization. Multi-step deduction is enabled via Monte Carlo Tree Search and Evolutionary Proof Search, guided by learned value functions and semantic unification.

AI.tldr: A neuro-symbolic architecture called Mathesis encodes logic states as hypergraphs and uses a Symbolic Reasoning Kernel to train a transformer model with gradient signals for energy minimization.
AI.motivation: The lack of an internal axiomatic framework for logical reasoning in LLMs leads to persistent logical failures in complex reasoning. The goal of the proposed architecture is to overcome this limitation.
AI.method: Multi-step deduction is enabled by Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) and Evolutionary Proof Search, guided by learned value functions and semantic unification.
AI.result: The approach turns proof search into an energy minimization task. The Symbolic Reasoning Kernel provides gradient signals to train a transformer-based model. The architecture integrates symbolic constraints with neural training.
AI.conclusion: This paper concludes with an architecture that integrates symbolic reasoning operations with deep learning. It is able to learn representations inductively. This is a promising direction for scalable and robust automated reasoning with LLMs.

title: SSI-GAN: Semi-Supervised Swin-Inspired Generative Adversarial Networks for Neuronal Spike Classification
summary: Mosquitos are the main transmissive agents of arboviral diseases. Manual classification of their neuronal spike patterns is very labor-intensive and expensive. Most available deep learning solutions require fully labeled spike datasets and highly preprocessed neuronal signals. This reduces the feasibility of mass adoption in actual field scenarios. To address the scarcity of labeled data problems, we propose a new Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) architecture that we call the Semi-supervised Swin-Inspired GAN (SSI-GAN). The Swin-inspired, shifted-window discriminator, together with a transformer-based generator, is used to classify neuronal spike trains and, consequently, detect viral neurotropism. We use a multi-head self-attention model in a flat, window-based transformer discriminator that learns to capture sparser high-frequency spike features. Using just 1 to 3% labeled data, SSI-GAN was trained with more than 15 million spike samples collected at five-time post-infection and recording classification into Zika-infected, dengue-infected, or uninfected categories. Hyperparameters were optimized using the Bayesian Optuna framework, and performance for robustness was validated under fivefold Monte Carlo cross-validation. SSI-GAN reached 99.93% classification accuracy on the third day post-infection with only 3% labeled data. It maintained high accuracy across all stages of infection with just 1% supervision. This shows a 97-99% reduction in manual labeling effort relative to standard supervised approaches at the same performance level. The shifted-window transformer design proposed here beat all baselines by a wide margin and set new best marks in spike-based neuronal infection classification.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces SSI-GAN, a semi-supervised GAN model for classifying mosquito neurons to detect viral infections, achieving high accuracy with minimal labeled data and reducing manual labeling effort by 97-99%.
AI.motivation: Manual classification of mosquito neuronal spike patterns for detecting viral neurotropism in arboviral diseases is labor-intensive and expensive. Existing deep learning approaches require extensive labeled data and preprocessing, hindering practical field use. To address the scarcity of labeled data, a new semi-supervised method is needed to improve feasibility.
AI.method: The authors propose the Semi-supervised Swin-Inspired GAN (SSI-GAN), featuring a Swin-inspired, shifted-window discriminator and a transformer-based generator. The discriminator uses multi-head self-attention in a flat, window-based transformer to capture sparse high-frequency spike features. The model is trained with 1-3% labeled data from over 15 million spike samples post-infection, optimized using Bayesian Optuna framework, and validated via fivefold Monte Carlo cross-validation.
AI.result: SSI-GAN reached 99.93% classification accuracy on the third day post-infection with only 3% labeled data. It maintained high accuracy across all infection stages with just 1% supervision, reducing manual labeling effort by 97-99% compared to standard supervised methods.
AI.conclusion: The SSI-GAN model outperforms all baselines, setting new benchmarks for spike-based neuronal infection classification. Its semi-supervised approach with minimal labeled data enhances feasibility for real-field application in detecting viral neurotropism.

Sweeping threshold epsilon produces smooth risk-coverage tradeoffs, reducing error rates f
